questions.text: Based on the properties of viruses, which of the following sentences is not true?

choices.text: A virus can either possess DNA or RNA, but never both.
All animal viruses are spherical in shape.
Viruses are obligate intracellular and can only replicate inside a host cell.
All viruses have a protein coat that encases their genetic material.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) All animal viruses are spherical in shape

 

Explanation:

Animal viruses have different shapes, but most are spherical.

 

General properties of viruses

Characteristics

  • They do not have a cellular organisation.
  • Obligate intracellular parasites - cannot replicate outside a host. (Option C)
  • Lack enzymes necessary for protein and nucleic acid synthesis.
  • Multiply via a complex process.
  • They cannot be cultured in cell-free culture media but can grow in embryonated eggs or tissue culture.
  • They can pass through filters.

Morphology

  • All viruses have a protein coat that encases their genetic material.
  • Either possess DNA or RNA but never both. (Option A)
  • Nucleic acid is enclosed by a protein capsid, which may or may not be enclosed by a lipid envelope. (Option D)

Shape
  • Most are spherical. (Option B)
  • Some are irregular and pleomorphic
  • Different shapes of animal viruses are
    • Rabies virus - bullet-shaped
    • Ebola virus - filamentous
    • Pox virus - brick shaped
    • Tobacco mosaic virus - rod-shaped

Size

Ranges from 300 nm - Poxvirus to 20 nm - Parvovirus

questions.text: A 34-year-old researcher accidentally exposes a viral sample to alcohol during a lab procedure. He recalls that alcohol can disrupt certain viral structures. Which of the following statements is true regarding the structure of viral envelopes and capsids?

choices.text: Hemagglutinin is a protein subunit found exclusively in non-enveloped viruses.
Non-enveloped viruses are more alcohol labile than enveloped viruses.
Viral envelope is composed of lipids derived from the host cell membrane.
Capsid in enveloped viruses gives the virus its pleomorphic shape.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Viral envelope is composed of lipids derived from the host cell membrane.

 

Explanation:

The viral envelope is composed of lipids derived from the host cell membrane when the progeny virus is released by budding.

 

STRUCTURE OF VIRUS

CAPSID: Protein coat surrounding the viral nucleic acid.
  • It is composed of small morphological units called capsomeres
  • The polypeptide molecules are arranged symmetrically
  • It forms an impenetrable shell around the nucleic core
  • It is adsorbed by the host cell membrane readily, thus introducing the viral genome into the host

ENVELOPED: Viral capsid is surrounded by a lipid membrane
  • It is derived from the host cell membrane by viral progeny during the budding process (Option C)
  • They have protein subunits that project on the envelope surface (Peplomers), which are viral-coded
  • The shape of the virus depends on the lipid envelope. (Option D)
  • Example (Option A)
    • Influenza virus has two types of peplomers:
      • Hemagglutinin: Triangular spike.
      • Neuraminidase: Mushroom-shaped structure.
  • Functions:
    • Confers chemical, antigenic, and biological properties.
    • Facilitates attachment to host cell surfaces.
    • Aids in processes such as hemagglutination
  • Enveloped viruses are sensitive to lipid solvents, including Ether, Chloroform and Bile salts.
  • Specific neutralisation of virus infectivity is mediated by antibodies targeting surface antigens.
  • Some viruses may have unique structural features, e.g., fibrils protruding from the vertices of adenovirus particles.

NON-ENVELOPED: Lack the lipid membrane, and viral capsid is naked
  • They lack the lipid membrane
  • More resistant to lipid solvents (Option B)
  • The shape of the virus depends on the shape of the capsid (Option D)

 

Most viruses are enveloped except:

  • Naked DNA viruses: Parvovirus, Papavovirus and Adenovirus
  • Naked RNA viruses: Picornaviruses, reovirus, calicivirus, astroviridae, Hep A and Hep E

questions.text:
Three patients come to the hospital, each presenting with three different infectious diseases.


	Patient A has Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease.
	Patient B has Potato spindle tuber viroid disease.
	Patient C has an Influenza type B infection.


Which option correctly describes the composition of each pathogen?

choices.text:
Patient A: Nucleic acids only

Patient B: Protein and nucleic acids

Patient C: RNA only

Patient A: Infectious protein only

Patient B: Naked circular ssRNA without a capsid

Patient C: Enveloped RNA

Patient A: Enveloped RNA

Patient B: Infectious protein only

Patient C: Naked circular ssRNA without a capsid

Patient A: Enveloped RNA

Patient B: RNA only

Patient C: Protein and nucleic acids

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Patient A: Infectious protein only; Patient B: Naked circular ssRNA without a capsid; Patient C: Enveloped RNA

Explanation:

  • Patient A (Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease) is caused by a prion, an infectious protein.
  • Patient B (Potato spindle tuber viroid) involves a viroid, a naked circular ssRNA without a capsid.
  • Patient C (Influenza type B) involves an enveloped RNA virus.

 

 

VIRUS

VIROID

PRION

Definition

Infectious agent composed of nucleic acid enclosed in a protein coat with or without a lipid envelope. (Patient C)

Infectious molecule composed of small, circular ssRNA without a capsid. (Patient B)

Infectious agent, composed of only infectious proteins.

(Patient A)

Composition

DNA/RNA + protein +/- Lipid.

RNA only.

Protein only.

Replication

Replicates using host cellular machinery

Replicates using host cellular machinery.

Replicates by inducing protein misfolding in the host.

Stability

Stability varies

Enveloped viruses are sensitive to lipid solvents, while non-enveloped are more resistant.

Resistant to heat and organic solvent.

Resistant to heat and proteolytic enzymes and heat, it can remain infectious for years.

Examples

Influenza virus, Poxvirus, Reovirus

Potato spindle tuber viroid,

Plant diseases

Creutzfeldt-jakob disease

Virion: Complete virus particle that includes a genome and a protein coat, which exists outside of host cells, representing one of the physical forms of a virus during a specific phase of its replication cycle.

questions.text:
Identify the mismatched pair of viruses and their site of viral replication.

1. Adenovirus - Cytosol

2. Poxvirus - Cytosol

3. Parvovirus - Nucleus

4. HIV - Mixed
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Adenovirus - Cytosol

Explanation:

Adenovirus - Cytosol is a mismatched pair because adenovirus is a DNA virus that replicates in the nucleus, similar to most DNA viruses.

  • Most DNA viruses replicate within the nucleus of the host cells, with a few exceptions, such as poxvirus, which replicates in the cytosol (Option A).
  • Examples of DNA viruses: Hepadna virus, Reovirus, Parvovirus (Option C), Adenovirus (Option B) and Papovavirus
  • Most RNA viruses replicate in the cytosol of the host cells except for orthomyxovirus and retroviruses(HIV) (Option D), which synthesise their RNA in the nucleus.

questions.text: Based on the steps of viral replication, label the following diagram

choices.text: A - Attachment, B - Translation, C- Transcription, D- budding
A - Penetration, B - Translation, C- Transcription, D- budding
A - Penetration, B - Transcription, C- Translation, D - Maturation
A - Attachment, B - Transcription, C- Translation, D- Maturation

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) A - Penetration, B - Transcription, C- Translation, D - Maturation

Explanation:

  • The above diagram shows the steps of viral replication within the host cell, and the labelling is A - Penetration, B - Transcription, C- Translation, D - Maturation.

 

VIRAL REPLICATION

Attachment:

  • Receptor interaction between viral surface antigen and host cell surface antigens.
  • HIV: Viral surface gp120 binds to CD 24 on host cells.
  • Influenza: Viral hemagglutinin binds to glycoprotein receptors on respiratory epithelium

Penetration: Viral particle enters the host cells via -

  • Phagocytosis/viropexis (receptor mediated endocytosis occurs)
  • Membrane fusion (some enveloped viruses enter via fusion of their membrane with the host cell membrane; thus, only the nucleocapsid enters).
  • Injection of nucleic acid by bacteriophages.

Uncoating: Host cell lysosomal enzymes separate the viral capsid and nucleic acid.

Biosynthesis

  • Nucleic acid replication
    • DNA viruses replicate within the nucleus except for the Pox virus, which replicates in the cytosol.
    • RNA viruses replicate within the cytosol except retroviruses and orthomyxoviruses
  • Transcription of Viral nucleic material
    • DNA viruses: DNA is transcribed into RNA in the mRNA in the cytosol.
    • + sense RNA viruses: Directly replicated/transcribed or translated
    • - sense RNA viruses: Transcribed into +ve sense RNA first, which is then replicated
    • dsRNA viruses
      • +ve strand is directly replicated/transcribed or translated.
      • -ve strand is transcribed into +ve sense RNA first.
      • Both strands can serve as templates for complementary strands
    • In retroviruses, reverse transcription converts viral single-stranded RNA (ssRNA) into double-stranded DNA (dsDNA), which is then integrated into the host genome.
  • Translation: Viral RNA is translated to form viral protein, which can be packed into progeny viruses.

Assembly: Viral nucleic acid and protein are packed together to form new viral progeny.

  • DNA viruses are assembled in the nucleus except Poxvirus and Hepadnavirus.
  • RNA viruses are assembled in the cytosol.

Maturation: The daughter virions mature in the nucleus/cytosol/membranes (Golgi Apparatus or endoplasmic reticulum or plasma membrane.

RELEASE

  • Lysis of cells: Usually occurs in non-enveloped viruses and bacteriophages.
  • Budding: occurs in enveloped viruses.
    • During budding, the virus acquires a part of the host membrane, leading to envelope formation.

questions.text: During the production of a viral vaccine using embryonated hen’s eggs, which site is specifically utilised for the cultivation of yellow fever virus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Allantoic Sac

 

Explanation:

The Allantoic sac is the site specifically used for cultivating the yellow fever virus, providing a larger cavity for better viral yield.

 

Isolation of Viruses: Viruses cannot be grown on artificial culture media but are cultivated through various methods, including animal inoculation, embryonated egg inoculation, or tissue cultures.

  • Animal Inoculation: Used for the primary isolation of certain viruses, such as:
  • Arboviruses
  • Coxsackieviruses
  • Both these are isolated in the brain of suckling mice.
  • Egg Inoculation:

  • Yolk Sac: Useful for cultivating:
    • Arboviruses (e.g., Japanese encephalitis virus)
    • Bacteria (e.g., Rickettsia, Chlamydia, Haemophilus ducreyi).
  • Amniotic Sac: Used for isolating the Influenza virus
  • Allantoic Sac: A larger cavity that provides better yields for viral vaccines, including:
    • Influenza
    • Yellow fever (17D)
  • Chorioallantoic Membrane: Employed for isolating poxviruses (Eg, vaccinia and variola) & herpes simplex viruses (HSV-1, HSV-2), which produce visible lesions known as pocks on the membrane.

questions.text: A researcher needs to isolate a virus using a cell line that can divide a maximum of 10 to 50 times before senescence. Which of the following cell lines should they choose?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) MRC-5 Cell Line

 

Explanation:

questions.text: A patient’s cell culture exhibits distinct cytopathic effects characterised by the formation of syncytia (multinucleated giant cells). Based on these observations, which virus is most likely responsible for the infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Measles virus

 

Explanation:

  • Syncytia formation is a characteristic cytopathic effect associated with measles virus infection, distinguishing it from other viruses.
  • This occurs due to the fusion of infected cells, resulting in multinucleated giant cells.
  • While the Herpes simplex virus can also cause syncytia, measles is more characteristically associated with this effect in cell cultures.
  • Adenovirus and enterovirus typically do not exhibit syncytia formation.

 

Detection of Virus Growth in Cell Cultures:

  • Cytopathic Effect (CPE) refers to the morphological changes induced by a virus in a cell line, which can be observed using a light microscope.
  • While not all viruses cause CPE, those are known as cytopathic viruses.
  • Each virus has a unique type of CPE that helps to identify:
    • Enteroviruses (Option B): Rapid CPE with cell crenation and degeneration.
    • Measles virus: Syncytium formation (RSV or respiratory syncytial virus).
    • Herpesvirus: Discrete focal degeneration, ballooning and syncitium formation.
    • Adenovirus (Option A): Large granular clumps resembling bunches of grapes.
    • SV40 or Simian virus 40 (Option D): Prominent cytoplasmic vacuolation.
  • Metabolic Inhibition: Cellular metabolism produces acid in normal cultures, causing a colour change in the medium's pH indicator (phenol red).
  • When viruses grow, metabolism gets inhibited, leading to reduced acid production and a colour change.
  • Hemadsorption: Hemagglutinating viruses, such as influenza, can be detected by adding guinea pig erythrocytes to the culture.
    • If the viruses replicate, the erythrocytes will adsorb onto the cell surfaces.
  • Interference: The presence of a non-cytopathogenic virus inhibits the growth of a subsequent challenge with a known cytopathogenic virus.
  • Transformation: Oncogenic viruses can induce cell transformation, leading to loss of contact inhibition and the formation of microtumors in culture.

Other Methods for Detecting Viral Growth:

  • Direct Immunofluorescence Assay detects viral antigens on the surface of cells.
  • Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) is used to detect viral genes.
  • Electron Microscopy allows visualisation of viruses within infected cell lines.
  • Shell Vial Technique: For viruses like CMV, which require several weeks to exhibit CPE, the shell vial technique offers a quicker detection method (1-2 days).

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with neurological symptoms, and a brain biopsy is performed, revealing the presence of inclusion bodies as shown in the image. What are these inclusion bodies commonly referred to as?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Negri Bodies

 

Explanation:

Negri bodies are characteristic intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions found in the brain cells of animals infected with rabies, which causes neurological symptoms.

 

Inclusion bodies:

  • Characteristic histological features observed in virus-infected cells exhibiting distinct sizes, shapes, locations and staining properties.
  • Types:
    • Cytoplasmic inclusion bodies
    • Nuclear inclusion bodies
    • Both cytoplasmic and nuclear
  • Inclusion bodies are generally acidophilic and appear as pink structures when stained with the Giemsa method or eosin methylene blue.
  • Certain viruses, such as adenovirus, may produce basophilic inclusions.
  • Intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies:
    • Negri bodies: Intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions found in the brain cells of animals, indicative of rabies.
  • Paschen body (Option A): Variola virus
  • Guarnieri bodies: Smaller, multiple inclusions in cells infected by vaccinia virus
  • Bollinger bodies (Option C): Large inclusions observed in fowlpox.
  • Molluscum bodies (Option D): HP bodies (Henderson Patterson Bodies) - Very large inclusion bodies (20-30 µm) found in molluscum contagiosum.
  • Perinuclear cytoplasmic body: Reovirus
  • Classification of Intranuclear Inclusion Bodies:
    • Cowdry type A inclusions: Variable in size with a granular appearance & associated with:
      • Torres body: Yellow fever virus
      • Lipschultz body: Herpes simplex virus
    • Cowdry type B inclusions: More circumscribed and often multiple, seen in:
      • Adenovirus (basophilic)
      • Poliovirus
  • Intracytoplasmic and intranuclear inclusion bodies:
    • Owl’s eye appearance: Cytomegalovirus (CMV)
    • Measles virus (Warthin Finkeldey Giant Cell)

questions.text: A new respiratory virus has emerged in a rural community, with early reports indicating a high transmission rate and increased hospitalisations. Public health officials must evaluate the virus's infectivity to implement effective control measures. Which of the following assays is most appropriate for quantifying the virus's infectivity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Plaque Assay

 

Explanation:

  • The Plaque assay is the most suitable method for quantifying viral infectivity, as it allows for the determination of the number of infectious viral particles based on the formation of plaques in a cell culture.
  • Each plaque represents an area of localised infection caused by a single infectious unit of the virus, providing a direct count of viral infectivity.
  • The endpoint assay (Option A) measures the highest dilution, which still produces a specific effect but does not provide a direct count.
  • Electron microscopy (Option B) is used to visualise viral particles.
  • Haemagglutination (Option D) detects viral activity but does not quantify it.

 

Viral assays:

  • Viral enumeration
    • Electron microscopy: The ratio of a virus suspension mixed with latex particles, as observed under an electron microscope (negative staining), indicates the virus count.
    • Hemagglutination: RBCs are added to a serial dilution of a virus sample (with H spikes) to determine the hemagglutination titer; the highest dilution showing RBC agglutination indicates the number of virions.
  • Viral infective assays

 

Assay

Description

Endpoint assay

They are used for infectivity titration, for example, animal mortality, hemagglutinin production in allantoic fluid, and the appearance of cytopathic effects (CPE) in cell cultures.

Plaque assay

Agar is poured over a viral specimen on a cell line, revealing visible plaques (localised focus) of infected cells. The number of plaques corresponds to the infective virions.

Pox assay

Assessed by counting the number of pocks formed on the chorioallantoic membrane (CAM) from the appropriate viral inocula (Eg, Vaccinia)
